thread.title: Blue Jays fans cling to hope for Game 5
thread.title_full: Blue Jays fans cling to hope for Game 5 | Toronto Star

author: David Bateman
title: Blue Jays fans cling to hope for Game 5
text:
Blue Jays fans are desperately hoping for another against-the-odds comeback to keep their World Series hopes alive.
If the Jays are able to come back against the Kansas City Royals in the American League Championship Series, three straight do-or-die games await.
Game 5 is at 4 p.m. at the Rogers Centre .
The emotional roller coaster continues for fans enjoying the first Toronto post-season baseball in 22 years.
Flashback to the ALDS, and a 14-inning loss in Game 2 against the Texas Rangers put them down 2-0 in the best-of-five series. And in a hectic Game 5 seventh inning, they smashed their way into the next round against the Royals.
On Wednesday, Jays fans prepared themselves to go through it all again.
Adam Mamak has come prepared to cheer at the Rogers Centre — the fan has brought a hand-made sign featuring Donald Duck praising Josh Donaldson.
But after Tuesday’s bloodbath in Game 4, his nerves are “shot,” he says.
“I think if you weren’t concerned there’d be problems,” he said.
Still, he holds out hope.
“We’ve done it before, we’re not the only team to have been down.”
Mark Hildebrandt has seen the Jays comeback potential first hand. He was at Game 5 of the ALDS when the Jays came back against the Rangers.
“I think they can do it, they won the last three in the last series,” he said.
“They thrive in adversity.”
During that game, Hildebrandt felt sparks could fly at any moment. But Game 5 against the Royals feels more like "the end of the road."
He concedes the Royals have shown themselves to be an excellent team, and today might just be it for the Jays.
“They’ve got a good team going, we can make another run at it next year,” Hildebrandt said.
There won’t be fans perched at the Bird’s Nest in Nathan Phillips Square, where hundreds of people have congregated for previous games to watch it on the big screen. The area had been previously booked for a fundraising event .
— with files from Robin Levinson King
